newsitem.title: PAPUA NEW GUINEA: PNG police probe report of poll candidate shooting.
newsitem.headline: PNG police probe report of poll candidate shooting.

text.p: Papua New Guinea police said on Wednesday they were investigating reports that an independent candidate for the South Pacific nation's coming election had been shot dead.
Papua New Guinea's Post-Courier newspaper reported on Wednesday that Patterson Kila was shot at close range on Tuesday outside a friend's home in Port Moresby by men who had demanded his car keys.
"We are investigating and we can't say anything until the man's family have been informed," deputy police commisssioner Kembu Ludwick told Reuters.
Papua New Guinea voters are due to begin voting this Saturday in one of the country's most important elections since winning independence from Australia 22 years ago.
The country was plunged into crisis in March over plans by Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan to hire mercenaries to put down a nine-year secessionist rebellion on nearby Bougainville island.
Chan stood aside while a commission of inquiry examined a US$36 million deal to hire African mercenaries through the London-based military consultancy Sandline International.
Chan resumed his post last week after saying the inquiry had cleared him of any wrongdoing.
The Post-Courier also reported Chan's helicopter was attacked while he was campaigning in the rugged Highlands region, but a spokesman said the incident was not related to the election.
Chan's spokesman said a man became alarmed when the helicopter's engine was started and responded by throwing a rock at it.
The spokesman said Chan was 200 metres away at the time and was unhurt. Damage to the helicopter was minor and it was back in service soon after, he said.
A nationwide dusk-to-dawn curfew and liquor ban begin on Wednesday in a bid to stop election violence.
